content:
Diagnosis:	Metastatic gallbladder neuroendocrine carcinoma

Management:	2023 Oct - Extended cholecystectomy with lymph node dissection
		2023 Nov-Jan - 3 cycles carboplatin/etoposide
		2024 Feb - Palliative radiotherapy to T8 metastasis

Histology:	Poorly differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma, synaptophysin positive, Ki67 80%

Current Situation:	Progressive disease with deteriorating performance status

I reviewed [redacted name] today who attended with her husband. Unfortunately, she has experienced significant clinical deterioration over the past three weeks. Her performance status has declined from 1 to 3, and she now requires assistance with most daily activities. She describes worsening right upper quadrant pain requiring increased doses of opiates, and new onset lower back pain which is affecting her mobility. Her appetite has significantly decreased, and she reports a 4kg weight loss since our last review.

The recent CT scan from 15th March 2024 shows progressive disease with enlarging liver metastases, the largest now measuring 8.2cm compared to 5.6cm six weeks ago. There are also new bone metastases in the thoracic spine (T6, T8) and left acetabulum. Her liver function has deteriorated with bilirubin now at 45 and ALT 156.

We had a detailed discussion about the challenging situation. Given her poor performance status and rapid disease progression despite first-line platinum-based chemotherapy, I have explained that further systemic therapy would carry significant risks with limited potential benefit. [redacted name] and her husband understand this and agree with focusing on symptom management.

I have increased her MST Continus to 60mg BD and arranged urgent referral to our palliative care team. I've also requested an urgent MRI spine to assess for cord compression risk given her new back pain. The acute oncology team will review her tomorrow for consideration of urgent radiotherapy to the acetabular metastasis. I have provided emergency contact numbers and arranged weekly telephone follow-up with our specialist nurse team.
